By understanding these concepts, you are now equipped to critically evaluate and apply biometric technologies in various real-world applications.
output.introduction: Welcome to the Intermediate Biometrics course! This course builds upon foundational knowledge and delves deeper into the principles, technologies, and applications of biometric systems. We will explore various biometric modalities, performance evaluation metrics, security vulnerabilities, and ethical considerations. This course is designed for individuals with some prior exposure to biometrics or related fields.

chapters.description: This module introduces the fundamental concepts of biometrics, including definitions, history, and applications.
Explore various biometric modalities such as fingerprint, face, iris, voice, and gait recognition.
Understand the key components of a biometric system, including sensor, feature extraction, matching, and decision-making.
Delve into the details of fingerprint recognition, including image acquisition, feature extraction (minutiae), and matching algorithms.
Explore face recognition techniques, including 2D and 3D face recognition, feature extraction methods (e.g., Eigenfaces, Fisherfaces), and matching algorithms.
Understand the principles of iris recognition, including iris image acquisition, segmentation, feature extraction, and matching algorithms.

Learn about performance evaluation metrics for biometric systems, including False Acceptance Rate (FAR), False Rejection Rate (FRR), Equal Error Rate (EER), and Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curves.
Discuss the factors that can affect the performance of biometric systems, such as environmental conditions, user behavior, and sensor quality.
Explore commonly used benchmarking datasets for evaluating biometric algorithms and systems.
Identify potential security vulnerabilities in biometric systems, including spoofing attacks, presentation attacks, and template database attacks.
Explore security measures to mitigate vulnerabilities, such as liveness detection, biometric encryption, and template protection techniques.
Discuss ethical considerations related to the use of biometrics, including privacy, data security, and potential for bias.
